data.title: Opinion: Robert Lepage's Kanata and SLĀV have the same major flaws
authors: Quincy Armorer, Mathieu Murphy-Perron and PJ Prudat, Special to Montreal Gazette
data.meta_description: "The furore over SLĀV should have been enough for Lepage and his colleagues to press pause on yet another project about certain communities without those communities’ explicit participation."
data.text:
"The furore over SLĀV should have been enough for Lepage and his colleagues to press pause on yet another project about certain communities without those communities’ explicit participation."

Article content

Artistic depictions of history are essential for healthy and informed communities, but as the recent SLĀV debacle demonstrates, this should not give all artists carte blanche to share these stories in any which way they please.

SLĀV director Robert Lepage is one of Canada’s most esteemed theatre artists, and though his work has garnered international praise, he has been no stranger to criticism about equitable representation and cultural appropriation. Many defended SLĀV by citing the importance of better understanding the past in order to comprehend the world around us. While there is certainly merit to this argument, it is undone when artists fail to involve the communities from which these histories are drawn.

Article content

Many Canadians and Québécois are unaware of their own history, as made clear by audience reaction to Black Theatre Workshop and Tableau D’Hôte Theatre’s 2017 production of Lorena Gale’s Angélique. The play tells the story of Marie-Josèphe Angélique, an enslaved woman executed in 1734 for allegedly setting a fire that ravaged Old Montreal. Despite the historical significance of this story, Marie-Josèphe is barely a footnote in mainstream history books and few remember her name.

Even as the debate over SLĀV continues, another Lepage-centred controversy is brewing. His upcoming production of Kanata, a retelling of Canadian history through “the prism of relations between whites and natives,” faces growing scrutiny. Though Lepage did finally sit down with Indigenous artists to discuss the project this week, one wonders why it took an open letter signed by several prominent Indigenous artists for the meeting to take place. The furore over SLĀV should have been enough for Lepage and his colleagues to press pause on yet another project about certain communities without those communities’ explicit participation.

Article content

Canada frames its narrative as being a welcoming and inclusive nation, that the paradigm of a giant melting pot of cultures where all are accepted stands in sharp contrast to the bigotry and xenophobia of our southern neighbour. In reality, the parallels are far greater than most Canadians are willing to admit.

Additionally, although Canada puts itself on a pedestal of intercultural excellence, the diverse voices, faces and stories of the people that make up this country are marginally represented on its screens and stages. Lepage’s artistic “colour-blindness” is rooted in white privilege and illustrates how he and others are woefully unaware of the colonial lens that encourages white artists to claim Indigenous and racialized stories as their own.

It is all the more frustrating that in those rare moments when such stories receive the funding and platform necessary for popular consumption, artists from these communities are absent from the creative process. Not only does this erasure impoverish these artists, it ultimately weakens the stories being told.

Article content

In Angélique, the playwright shed light on Canada’s seldom-discussed history of slavery and delved into the enslavement of Indigenous people. Two-thirds of the slaves in the colony of New France were, in fact, Indigenous. It would have been unconscionable to cast a white actress in the role of Manon, the Indigenous Panis who befriended the titular character in the play.

Lepage, as one of the most powerful theatre creators in the world, should have leveraged his clout to ensure Indigenous artists were integral to every facet of Kanata. It is his privilege and responsibility to make space for Indigenous creators on the subject of the colonization of Indigenous lands and peoples in what became Canada. Our communities and our ancestors did not survive this long only to be excluded from telling our own stories.

Quincy Armorer is artistic director of Black Theatre Workshop. Mathieu Murphy-Perron is the artistic producer of Tableau D’Hôte Theatre. PJ Prudat is a Métis actor and writer who performs in the upcoming production of Angélique, which tours Ontario in 2019. The French translation will be presented at a staged reading at Centre du Théâtre d’Aujourd’hui in December.
